column2: also ; French pronunciation: [fɔʁ də fʁɑ̃s] (listen); French Antillean Creole: Fodfwans) is the capital of Martinique
column3: an overseas department of France located in the Caribbean. It is also one of the major cities in the Caribbean.
nephew of Pierre Belain d'Esnambuc and first governor of Martinique
column4: decided to have Fort Saint Louis built to protect the city against enemy attacks. The fort was soon destroyed
column6: when Louis XIV appointed the Marquis of Baas as governor general. Under his orders and those of his successors
column8: the fort was built with a Vauban design.

column2: the administrative capital of Martinique was over-shadowed by Saint-Pierre
column3: the oldest city in the island
column4: which was renowned for its commercial and cultural vibrancy as "The Paris of the Caribbean".

column1: The name of Fort-Royal was changed to a short-lived "Fort-La-Republique" during the French Revolution
column2: and finally settled as Fort-de-France sometime in the 19th century. The old name of Fort-Royal is still used today familiarly in its Creole language form of "Foyal"
column3: with the inhabitants of the city being "Foyalais".

column1: The city had its share of disasters
column2: being captured by a British expedition in 1762
column3: partially destroyed by an earthquake in 1839 and devastated by fire in 1890. At the turn of the 20th century
column5: Fort-de-France became economically important after the volcanic eruption of Mount Pelée destroyed the town of Saint-Pierre in 1902.

column3: Fort-de-France had an inadequate water supply
column5: and was notorious for yellow fever. Now the swamps are drained to make room for extensive suburbs.

column2: also known as the Fort of France
column3: lies on Martinique's west coast at the northern entrance to the large Fort-de-France Bay
column4: at the mouth of the Madame River. The city occupies a narrow plain between the hills and the sea but is accessible by road from all parts of the island.

column1: Fort-de-France has a tropical rainforest climate (Köppen Af)
column2: characterised by very warm to hot and humid weather year-round. The wettest months are from July to November when hurricanes are a frequent threat
column3: although substantial rainfall occurs in all months. The hottest month on average is September
column4: and the coldest month on average is February.

column1: Fort Saint Louis in Fort-de-France is a French naval base
column2: as is Dégrad des Cannes (French Guiana).

column1: The mayor is Didier Laguerre.  The commune of Fort-de-France makes up Martinique's 3rd constituency for the National Assembly.

column3: is in the gardens of La Savane. It was vandalized in the 1990s

column1: Martinique Aimé Césaire International Airport is located in a suburb outside Fort-de-France and is accessible via the A1 autoroute.
